data.title: Did Queen Mary, consort of George V, speak with a German accent?
data.text:
Categories Nooks and crannies Yesteryear Semantic enigmas The body beautiful Red tape, white lies Speculative science This sceptred isle Root of all evil Ethical conundrums This sporting life Stage and screen Birds and the bees

NOOKS AND CRANNIES

Did Queen Mary, consort of George V, speak with a German accent?

Trevor Harvey, Hove, UK

Wasn't Queen Mary Danish ?

Brian Robinson, Brentwood, Essex

History was the first subject that I dropped at school, but here goes.... The Danish princess was Alexandra - she and Edward VII were George V's parents. Mary was a princess born and raised in the UK, but with the title "Mary of Teck", since her father was a German Prince of Teck, in the Kingdom of WÃ¼rttemberg - so she may well have acquired something of a Teutonic accent at home as a child - before she married George V in 1893. If you follow this link: www.youtube.com/watch?v=PO9VEfOeOxo there is a rather faint recording of first George V, and then his consort Queen Mary reading 'Empire Day Messages to the Boys and Girls of the British Empire' (1923) - see vat you think! There were many marriages between British and German royalty, from the 17th century onwards, and German was often spoken in British royal households (apparently Queen Victoria and her German Prince Albert - the grandparents of George V - often conversed together at home in German). However, with anti-German feelings running very high in the UK during and after WWI, George V and the Royal Family increasingly tried to distance themselves from their German connections - including taking on the very British name of the "House of Windsor" (rather than "Saxe-Coburg & Gotha") in 1917. So, Queen Mary may in fact have tried very hard to emphasise her 'Britishness' and to NOT speak with any noticeably German accent.

W Boddy, Cambridge, UK

Also, Queen Mary's mother, Princess Mary Adelaide of Cambridge, was a 'member of the British Royal family', but with very German parents and ancestors - so no doubt there would have been lots of exposure to German accents for Mary of Teck while she was growing up.

W Boddy, Cambridge, UK
